nodes.text: A land price bubble can arise even when the observed housing rent to price ratio is stationary or nonvanishing, provided one distinguishes pure land rent from housing structure rent
Context: Skeptics reject rational land or housing bubbles because a bubble on a dividend-paying asset implies a vanishing dividend yield, while empirical price to rent ratios appear stationary

Model setup: two-period overlapping generations economy with consumption good and housing service, a unit supply of non-reproducible land, and Cobb-Douglas preferences with housing consumed when agents age

Firm technology: housing structure is produced by a representative firm using construction material M and land X with production function F(M,X) that is homogeneous of degree one, differentiable, concave, with FM>0, FX>0 and an Inada-type condition lim M->0 (FX/FM)(M,1)=0

Agents and markets: young have endowment e_t, buy land x_t and housing services h_t, old consume from selling land and receiving land dividend D_t; equilibrium defined by utility maximization, profit maximization, and market clearing

Budget aggregation yields optimal expenditures proportional to preference weights: expenditures (c_y, c_o/R, r_t h_t) = (beta_y e_t, beta_o e_t, beta_h e_t), and land price in equilibrium is P_t = beta_o e_t
Proposition 1: Aggregate housing rent to price ratio r_t h_t / P_t is constant and equals beta_h / beta_o (so housing rent yield can be stationary or constant)
Firm FOCs and market clearing imply 1 = r_t FM(M_t,1) and D_t = r_t FX(M_t,1), and housing market clearing gives condition F/FM(M_t,1) = beta_h e_t

Proposition 2 (existence and bubble criterion): There is a unique equilibrium and a land bubble exists iff the infinite sum over t of FX/F (M_t,1) is finite, where M_t solves the equilibrium condition
CES example: with F CES and elasticity of substitution sigma>1, asymptotics give FM/F ~ M^{-1} and FX/F ~ const * M^{1/sigma -1}, yielding Proposition 3 characterization

Proposition 3: For CES with sigma>1, a land bubble exists iff the sum over t of e_t^{1/sigma -1} is finite; in particular, if e_t grows geometrically (e_t ~ G^t with G>1) then the condition holds and land bubbles inevitably emerge with growth

Main implication and conclusion: Observed nonvanishing or constant housing rent yield does not rule out land bubbles because housing rent can be dominated by structure rent while pure land rent can vanish relative to land price; empirical work must separate land rent from structure rent to detect land bubbles

Limitation and recommendation: The model is minimal and deterministic; further empirical analysis and decomposition of rent into land and structure components are needed to assess existence of land bubbles
Supporting lemma (Bubble Characterization): An asset price exhibits a bubble iff the sum over t of dividend yield D_t / P_t is finite, linking vanishing dividend yield behavior to bubble existence
